posts.title: So... Who are we?
posts.markdown:
Making. Tinkering. STEAM. Makerspace. Project Leadership Learning. Heard any of these before? It’s likely you’ve heard a politician talking about its importance, or maybe you’ve seen a robotics program promoting these ideas. Google is one of the most avid proponents of these terms. But… uh. What do they mean? Why are they so important? What is it? 

Glad you asked! They’re the reason law makers and educational leaders are so excited about these concepts – and it’s not just because they get to write more syllabus points for kids to work through. People are excited because for the first time in a while (maybe ever…) education might actually be made fun. Taking pleasure in what you learn about is limitlessly better than being forced to learn something they have no ownership of. How is it better? Well apart from the obvious – that kids will retain more by learning about what they enjoy, it’s better for their life skills. 

Before we get into all that stuff – let’s cover the initial question; what is STEM, STEAM, tinkering, makerspaces etc.?  These are not new concepts necessarily – Making and Tinkering is what inventors have been doing for centuries, nay, millennia. It’s the process of creating, experimenting and improving ideas to solve a problem. These are the skills that created and formed the most successful, inspirational and impactful minds in history. Henry Ford was a maker and a tinkerer – he because revolutionary because he got his hands dirty. Leonardo Da Vinci was a genius – not because he knew how to write great essays or copy off a while-board; he is revered because he created, failed, tinkered again and made something brilliant. He didn’t learn by ‘learning’ he learnt by doing.

More recently, the idea of the Makerspace came to be – I assume this was created by someone who realised that school sucks and needs an update… or someone who thought – ‘I need a couch. But not any couch. A couch that drives itself… to the fridge. All I need is a place to make one.’ – thus the makerspace was born. A makerspace is simply an area that people – adults, kids, particularly clever dogs and alike can come in and create things using equipment like laser cutters, 3D printers, robotics parts and an assortment of tools. A makerspace is in its name: it’s a space where you make things. 

Makerspaces have been popping up around the world – and engineers and enthusiasts have been creating cool things for years. Now, that movement needs to come to children. I have every belief that kids will create more amazing and incredible things in a makerspace than any adult. Why? Kids don’t know the word no… or can’t… or won’t… or any of the above – they have an opportunity in makerspaces to understand why… or how… or what if? TinkerTank is exactly that movement – giving kids the tools that adults tend to keep for themselves and showing them how to use it – but never telling them that ‘it’s impossible’ to do what they dream of. It is super powerful, it will create better jobs, higher educational results and will help tie together curriculums across the board.

What’s next? The movement is new – makerspaces exist, but we need a sustainable, exciting and competitive market where kids are a priority and working with the curriculums in mind, achieving outcomes that inspire kids to create, collaborate and construct their way to a brighter tomorrow. This movement isn’t just done in physical spaces – it can be done at home, at schools and more! TinkerTank is moving in this direction to make it as easy as possible to Tinker anywhere you want. Our courses, soon our app, and our social pages will light up with fun at-home and in-school activities for everyone to do, with or without equipment.
 

 ~ James

~ James

posts.title: STEM Education: It's time to take it seriously. Like, properly, really seriously.
posts.markdown:
20% of all new jobs created year-on-year are STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) central. Another 60% on top of that involve the regular use of technology, including word processing, basic coding, computer troubleshooting and interaction with various mediums and forms of tech. In ten years time, it's expected that vehicles will have been mostly updated to self-driving; 30% of the US workforce are drivers: Uber, Trucking, Taxis, post, delivery etc. How do we, as a society stop our next generation from being replaced by robots - but rather, have them creating robots, or working in knowledge based fields, unlikely to be replaced by robots any time soon? Be the creator, the the innovator, understand the environment, work with the future and embrace our robot companions - they'll make us all much wealthier and much more efficient.

STEM is not a new concept. We've had all of these things for decades, centuries, millennia even! But it's never been more prevalent, important and critical than now to start inspiring more people to have a passion for STEM; to start making STEM central to the experience of growing up as a child in the 21st century.

Notice how I said 'passion'? That's because teaching STEM isn't useful. Don't just learn, do. Be passionate and love it - that doesn't happen when you teach it like everything else at school - text books, writing notes, remembering facts and writing essays about concepts and theories. STEM is about understanding the world better - it's about invoking ones' creativity and imagination to push the boundaries of what we as the human race know; we don't push the limits when we're not inspired.

When is the right time to start doing STEM? The earlier the better. Ever heard the term 'nerd'? Ever watched a TV show that depicted the science enthusiast as a socially awkward hermit? It's those stigmas that can stick as early as age 7 in both girls and boys, so let's get our children understanding what STEM really is (hint: the most kickass thing you can do) before popular culture tells them what to believe; let's start making crazy science and wild robots from an early age. On top of being super important, STEM in all forms is just super fun, exciting and a really cool skill to show off to others!

Want some good news, parents? STEM is super easy to teach, the internet has made it super simple to learn nearly anything you want. Want to know what a logic gate is? Wikipedia is more accurate than you know. Want to build your own sun-tracking solar panel? YouTube is a magical land of information. Want to be inspired for a engineering project? Forums are your best friend. There are so many resources out there to get working on - the hardest bit is finding the equipment to do it... Starting the STEM journey can be difficult - where do you start? What's doable, what's worth spending the money on? It may well be the case that your child just simply has no interest and may never have a massive interest in STEM - what a waste of money it could be to buy a $600 robotics kit only for it to never be used... I firmly believe that the right start to STEM is so important - and being shown the light of what they can do, working with your child to find something that interests them as well. Sadly, places that offer this kind of experience are rare and often vary greatly in style - ranging from school-like experiences (which may suit some people) to one-on-one sessions (also perfect for some); finding the right balance is difficult for many. TinkerTank offer a range of experience that works for you.

Whilst schools work out how to teach STEM and train their teachers to fit the most open ended subject matter into school time, TinkerTank is leading the way in inspiring kids and making STEM enjoyable.

TinkerTank is a Maker-Space. A place of creation and taking ideas and thought bubbles into real creations. TinkerTank is an EDUCATIONAL MakerSpace. A place of inspiring a passion for STEM and helping children turn their dreams into reality. TinkerTank is both of these things - for the experienced creator, and for the curious tinkerer. TinkerTank can 3D print, code, wire, robot, teach Ukulele and create awesome YouTube videos. TinkerTank can teach, and inspire and work with your child to make STEM engaging and interesting; helping your child find their interest - not making them tick syllabus boxes in a curriculum designed to generate as many society ready people as quickly as possible.

Let's start taking STEM education seriously - it's taken until 2016 for schools to start making it a priority, but it'll take much longer to iron out the kinks that make the process of learning STEM difficult for many. Whether you come to TinkerTank, or take up arms and start the path of a STEM future at home - the change is coming, and we need to be future ready.

posts.title: Kids. They're way more capable than you think they are. Give them a go!
posts.markdown:
I've been teaching children robotics for almost 6 years now. I started when I was 15 years old - running workshops and basic classes as part of a robotics team - we were teaching students from ages 5 and up.

Being new and what some might consider naive - I didn't actually consider age to be a massive barrier to ability. That is to say - I figured if you taught kids, and explained things in an engaging and interested way - they'd eventually understand. Turns out, that's totally true! Disclaimer: young children often struggle to retain information for long periods of time - so whilst the information 'churn' is real, continual work and reinforcement meant that Kindergartners were using 'greater than' and 'less than' to use sensors, or using gear ratios to make drag racers or winches to pull objects. 5 year olds understood that the more rigid a moving construction is (like a pulley or drive system), the less friction is generated when put under strain. 5 year old's were sharing ideas, and coming up with projects that many would say are: beyond their age.

These kids were not only applying ideas beyond their age - they were testing, experimenting and learning in a project based environment that mean these kids were overcoming barriers themselves and not just following instruction.

So, how did these students start to understand these concepts? And why is this important? I mean, their only 5, right? Age 5 is when most children start being schooled - this is where stigmas, and learning styles and friendships and so much is formed. Doing it right now - is more important than doing it right later in life. On top of this - the WAY kids learn and the WAY they are taught from a young age is so important.

Emotional maturity is something that comes with time, and so does the brain development required to retain large amounts of wrote learning. However, just like Dory in Finding Nemo - procedural knowledge (speaking, moving, interacting with people) is actually just fine, but declarative knowledge (recalling facts, names and other information) is weaker - this is the same with younger children. A young child at age 5 has the same amount of procedural knowledge and ability as a 14 or 15 year old kid. So how is teaching them things they'll forget useful? Well, teaching kids in a way that engages them, inspires them and makes them want to learn more, does several things:

Kids are no-longer having to wrote learn large amounts of information - they're discovering by doing.
By actually having teachers get kids to discover and learn things based on challenges they come across you get: high engagement from students; slightly higher information retention and...
Your teaching kids to OVERCOME barriers to a task. As oppose to limiting what kids think and dream up - you can get them to learn for themselves. What may shock you is: these kids will do things you never think of yourself to overcome the issue they face. No longer are these kids being told 'No. You can't. Don't.' they're being asked 'why not try something different? What do you think?' and they're being told 'I don't know, let's look it up. I'm sure there's another way. Well done! You failed, and that's awesome'. Getting kids to think about alternatives, and encouraging them to overcome barriers is super powerful.
Now, I mentioned failure in there as well: teaching kids to learn how to fail produces some epic results. No more is failure a reason to give up - it's a learning experience and reason to try again!

So next time you think about giving your kids something to do - try giving them a project and helping them do it, even if you don't know how yourself. Help them Google it, or keep trying things until it works. You'll start to raise children ready to tackle the unpredictable work, and ready to overcome challenge, not get shut down by it.

Stop saying 'you can't' or 'don't' or 'that's impossible' and start letting them learn and find out WHY something is the way it is. It'll make for a much more exciting childhood and a much more capable child!

Project based learning is applicable across all areas of study - heck, it's exactly what adults do in the workplace - have a challenge - then solve it. TinkerTank does exactly that. It gives kids challenges and topics to work on - then helps them accomplish that; not by telling them what to do or think, but by encouraging them to think, helping them access the right resources and showing them that they are much smarter than anyone gives them credit for.

If you live in Sydney, try it for yourself, goto TinkerTank.com.au and book a course. If you live anywhere else, try it at home and start doing projects that challenge your kids - don't underestimate them!

~James

posts.meta_title: Coding, Robotics, Home Schooling and STEM are tools more useful than you think for kids.
posts.meta_description: Kids are learning coding, robotics, STEAM subjects and more better than you think! It's time to have some faith in this new kind of schooling.

posts.title: Looking for STEAM solutions...
posts.markdown:
When we started out, TinkerTank was a ClubHouse for kids looking to create, collaborate and construct. 

During this journey, we grew along side the MakerSpace movement. Crafting our message and our mission to align with the ideal space for kids to learn through projects and play.

**SO MUCH CAN HAPPEN IN 1 YEAR**

Australia realised that they were drastically falling behind in just about all subjects. They tried to follow America and the rest of the world by giving the climb back up to the "present" with STEM. 

Australia attempted to get schools and corporations to jump on the band wagon, but most did not seem to fully understand why kids need to focus on STEM, now.

**WHAT THE HECK IS STEM, ANYWAY?** 

Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths.

Just when they did, America and the rest of the world added an "A" for Arts into the mix. **STEAM**.

Well, that was just way too confusing. Now, no one know what was more important.

The truth is , we all know that the current system is outdated and not very engaging. Big change is needed. We have made TinkerTank everything we would want our children to have in their learning environment. 

**With massive benefits and skills :**

1. Problem solving: Curiosity that children have leads to imperative critical thinking skills. They learn to rationalise and reason when learning about and even imagining a robots potential.  Robotics teaches fun, practical reasoning and problem solving that kids don’t even realise they are learning!

2. Decision making: Experiencing cause and effect, problem solving and critical thinking skills, on the fly decision-making - these are *basic* life skills. Building and programming robots fits with problem solving and taps directly into students natural curiosity, which is where great ideas and game-changing inventions are created.

3. Future-Proofing: Technology is rapidly advancing.  Kids around the world are being exposed to the advantages of learning STEAM and understanding their place in society today.  Others will be left at a distinct disadvantage when they leave school, with possibly fewer career and study opportunities than those who have already been exposed to the educational concept of what robotics can do and how they do it.



We have had to create this unique space, curriculum and experience from scratch. Nothing like it anywhere else in the world, and we are pretty proud of this. If you have not had a chance to pop in to see this all in action first hand, please do! 

If you want this experience in your School? We have great affordable packages available. 

Let's make STEAM more accessible, together!

posts.title: March-Madness!
posts.markdown:
**Mid way March already!** March has been full of magic.

We have had an incredible response to the Home Ed **Alternative School Membership** from Monday to Friday, 9am to 3pm. We now have 11 children from ages 6 up to 15! Fantastic kids!

Our **Term 1** courses just kept Booking! You may not know - TinkerTank courses can be started at any time. We help the *individual child* this means that they will work at their own pace.

**AfterSchool Workshops** are now changing, once again - we focus on STEAM through Robotics, Coding and Design, however, you can now start and stop whenever you like, and we just keep going year-round! If you want to stop, pop us an email and we can pause your subscription. It's all about giving you the choice and making it easy for everyone. None of this 'term' business - just fun, learning and skill building!

If you can't choose, we recommend a Membership! Great for High School students looking for a place to explore new tech and meet like minded people.

Of course, **Camps** are now booking up fast so get in soon. You can book camps [here.](https://app.tinkertank.ai/?source=sales&type=Camp)

Can't wait to see some familiar faces, and new ones too. 

Remember to help us out by telling a friend!

Julija
Founder

####[Book Now](https://app.tinkertank.ai/?source=sales&type=Camp)

posts.title: About TinkerTank
posts.markdown:
TinkerTank is a growing **STEAM** *(Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Mathematics)* community, welcoming people from all ages, disciplines and cultures that seek a deeper understanding of the world we live in, and that our children will grow into. 

We know that **STEAM** encourages reasoning and helps teach the type of thinking skills that 21st century adults are going to need in a world where almost everything will be enhanced by this.

TinkerTank is building a Mentorship base of the area's most inspired thinkers, doers and makers — and a community of curious kids to engage with ideas and each other, both online and at our TinkerTank HQ, all year long.

We're about changing education and turning it on it's head... just a little bit! We offer in-house holiday programs and afterschool courses as well as a comprehensive and unique school offering that could see your school have world-class facilities for free! 

We welcome you to start the conversation and reach out to us - we might just find a way to help you change **STEAM** education forever. 


>We passionately believe in the power that ideas can change attitudes, lives and, ultimately, the world.

We know that STEAM encourages reasoning and helps teach the type of thinking skills that 21st century adults are going to need in a world where almost everything will be enhanced by this.

TinkerTank is building a Mentorship base of the area's most inspired thinkers, doers and makers — and a community of curious kids to engage with ideas and each other, both online and at our TinkerTank HQ, all year long.

We're about changing education and turning it on it's head... just a little bit! We offer in-house holiday programs and afterschool courses as well as a comprehensive and unique school offering that could see your school have world-class facilities for free!

We welcome you to start the conversation and reach out to us - we might just find a way to help you change STEAM education forever.

We passionately believe in the power that ideas can change attitudes, lives and, ultimately, the world.

posts.title: Robotics
posts.markdown:
Robotics is the combination of design, coding and electronics. It's the real deal and it's super, super easy to get started!

TinkerTank's courses and holiday programs demonstrate just how easy it can be to create something entirely unique and new and have it interact with the world around you. Consider the potential! 

Our robotics program takes you under our wing - we help you build your skills and work towards being a robotics master!
###Outcomes
At our robotics workshops we collaborate with others to design, explore, experiment, and create unique machines. Understanding the balance and fine-tuning of your robots to make art work the way you imagine!

###Skills
* Evaluation and Problem Solving
* Creative and Design
* Team Work and Discussions
* Mathematical techniques
* Discussions, Communication and Reasoning
* Presenting their Work

###Pathway
We are building a bespoke series of courses that provide direct access to tertiary programs.

###Available in:
* Holiday Camps
* Afterschool Subscription
* Robotics competition Teams: FIRST Robotics

####[Shop Robotics](http://tinkertank.ai/course-listing.html#Robotics)

posts.title: Coding
posts.markdown:
Coding isn't just lines of words or gibberish - it's about understanding the way the world works! Anything with a computer has code - and being able to code means you can understand so much more about the world around you.

Future jobs will most likely involve coding or digital literacy - prepping yourself today to build the tech of the future, not be replaced by it is critical. What's crazy is: it's FUN! We focus on project based learning, giving advice and projects to work towards - and you leave having fun AND with something to take home.

###Outcomes
The benefits of learning programming at *ANY* age helps develop thinking, processing and communicating. These skills will later help you to be innovative, which will translate into nearly any profession. 

###Skills
* Evaluation and Problem Solving
* Creative and Design
* Team Work and Discussions
* Mathematical techniques
* Discussions, Communication and Reasoning
* Presenting their Work

###Pathways
We want the skills you learn here to get you places. We are building a bespoke series of courses that provide direct access to tertiary programs. Future Proof yourself and learn something new with TinkerTank.

###Available in:
* Holiday Camps
* After School Subscriptions


####[Shop Coding](http://tinkertank.ai/course-listing.html#coding)

posts.title: Design
posts.markdown:
Design isn't just making things pretty - it's about forming the way people interact with the world, creating new ideas and even new realities. 

This design subscription lets you choose your path or even try a little of everything. No matter your experience, age, or otherwise - you can try to create your own world and use design to make the world a little more interesting.

###Topics
* 3D Design and Printing
* Animation
* Game Design
* Design Thinking and Entrepreneurship
* Video Production

We're happy to let you try a little of everything, and then after a few weeks - we'd recommend you choose a pathway to focus on for a while to build skills in a certain area.

###Suitable For:
* Budding young designers
* Students interested in 3D Printing, Animation, Product Development, Game Design and Video Creation
* Students looking for a range of different activities in one class

###Outcomes
Design workshops at TinkerTank cover Digital Content Creation with our YouTube Course, Animation, 3D Printing and modeling, and more.

We will guide your children on a creative and inspiring journey that teaches theory and practical projects in creating and designing content and will learn the thought process behind design, developing an idea, the best ways to make it a reality.

###Skills
* Understand the thought process behind design
* Learn the base skills required to become a Designer (Digital Content Creation, 3D Designer, 3D Printing and more)
* Exploring platforms and available Software and technology
* Define your personal Design and content creation skills that interest you

###Pathways
We want the skills you learn here to get you places. We are building a bespoke series of courses that provide direct access to tertiary programs. Future Proof yourself and learn something new with TinkerTank.

###Available in:
* Holiday Camps
* After School Subscriptions

####[Shop Design](http://tinkertank.ai/course-listing.html#design)

posts.title: Term 1 Holidays - Book today!
posts.markdown:
TinkerTank is excited to have another set of holiday camps ready for booking - we've changed how we offer camps this holidays: Robotics and Coding remain largely unchanged - but our new category 'Design' is an aggregate experience that lets you choose a specialty for the day!

In the design camps you can choose From:

* 3D Printing
* Animation
* Video Creation
* YouTuber Skills
* Game Design

Robotics and coding are now for all ages 5+, we've removed the limitations for the use of equipment too! It doesn't matter if you're a pro or a rookie, we'll cater the experience to you. No longer do we break camps into 'Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced'. 

We hope to see you this holidays - it's going to be the best holidays yet!

Let your creativity fly this holidays! Try something new and different at TinkerTank and bring a friend!

Spots have started booking and they're going quickly - you can [book here](https://app.tinkertank.ai/?source=sales&type=Camp).

Can't wait to see you all!

#####[Book Now](https://app.tinkertank.ai/?source=sales&type=Camp)

posts.title: Ya... we kinda love our job.
posts.markdown:
**Mentors at TinkerTank**

**Julija McDowell** : *Founder + Futurist*

Worked for ILM, Lucas Film, Lucas Arts, Disney as a Lead animator and trainer in California for over 18 years. Julija has won multiple awards for her animation work, and has been nominated for Academy Awards. She has delivered lectures on animation at conferences around the world. Julija now works as a Curriculum writer, UX + App Designer and Arts Teacher. Her team was selected as a Startup Innovator by IBM in 2010. Recently her work was shortlisted for the Pollinator DataStart Project 2015 and a finalist in the EducationChangemakers Accelerator Program in Feb 2017. Julija is the "Futurist" and head Tinkerer at TinkerTank and loves every second of it.



**James McArthur** : *Generalist* 

James has been doing robotics since year 3 at school. Competing in several robotics competitions, and even winning the state LEGO Robotics Dance competition in year 4 – and has been really enthusiastic and passionate about STEAM education ever since. Now in university – continuing his passion for STEAM education at TinkerTank – creating courses, helping kids and making learning fun.

**Nicholas McDowell** : *Software* 

Nicholas is what we like to call a Serial-Entrepreneur with experience working with a diverse group of businesses — from Silicon Valley startups to the US Department of Defence. An inventor and tech-junkie at heart, on any given day you can find Nicholas ideating, developing, and testing innovative tech solutions to big and small problems. He dreams of one day surfing behind a (powerful) drone — we dare you to invent that one Nicholas!


**Fred Westing** : *Robotics/Coding*

Over the past eight years, Fred has been designing, programming and competing with robots at a national and international level. He believes robots are the future, and are inherently awesome — and we would have to agree. Fred is experienced in a wide array of programming languages and wants your kids to be prepared to design the software of tomorrow, which is why he is our expert coding Mentor.



**Tijana Williams** : *Animation*

For Tijana, simply creating beautiful designs wasn't enough — she wanted to make them move too. With degrees in graphic design and animation, Tijana adores animation in all of its forms. With a special love for stop-motion animation, Tijana is excited to share her knowledge of this medium with the next generation of creative thinkers.



**Stephanie Curro** : *Robotics*

Stephanie is a loud and proud girl in STEAM. She found robotics in year 5 after her Mum took her to her first class, and she’s been hooked ever since. She wants to empower the next generation of girls to become innovators and she works hard to inspire all the kids she teaches. She is currently completing her final year of schooling while competing on a FIRST Robotics Team at Macquarie University.



**Gary Osborne** : *Design*

Gary is a self-taught cabinet and furniture maker with an interest in the restoration of historical military hardware. Gary's enthusiasm for taking things apart, investigating how they work, and then building them into something new, makes him the perfect teacher of our Break it Down class. Did someone order a life-sized slingshot?



**Pippa May** : *Design*

Pippa is TinkerTank's walking Pinterest board; bursting with ideas for creative craft activities. With an Advanced Diploma of Fashion Design it is no wonder that Pippa's classes are hands-on, often textile focused, and include a sprinkling of design theory to boot. In Pippa's classes anything is possible.


**Karen Hopkins** : *Design*

As a Producer/Director Karen spends her days running around with a camera capturing colourful content to turn into exciting online videos. She purchased her first video camera at age 15 and now 15+ years later, she is still creating videos. With seven years of American summer camp under her belt Karen loves teaching and working with kids. She is a Manly local who loves yoga, sunrise swims and trips to the farmers market.


**Dragan** : *Intern*

Dragan is TinkerTank's youngest Mentor and resident MineCraft expert — he can literally answer any MineCraft question you have. When not teaching at TinkerTank Dragan can be found honing is craft with more MineCarft, as well as exploring code and animation. Dragan is a Manly local, keep an eye out for him skate-boarding down North Steyne!



**Erik** : *Intern*

Erik has found lots of interest in Maths, Engineering, Science & Robotics and has learnt Coding in a week at TinkerTank. TinkerTank expands his capability of learning. He has been awarded with multiple awards of Science, Mathematics and Robotics. He has a wonderful family of four, his family includes a younger Brother, a Mum and Dad as well as himself. One day he hopes to code software for TinkerTank or work as an Engineer.

posts.title: Don't be afraid. This STEAM doesn't burn.
posts.markdown:
Hey There! 

It’s me, you’re **lovable** ol’ pal James from TinkerTank. I’ve met many of you, and hope to meet many more of you in the future. 

I want to talk to you about STEAM. No, not the kind you use on your carpets to get the red-wine stains out. Or the kind that makes it impossible to see out your glasses when you open the oven...

TinkerTank is all about STEAM, which actually stands for Science. Technology. Engineering. Arts. and Mathematics. Being all about STEAM means we want to prepare your kids... and heck - even you - for the future of the workforce and society. 

Our workshops, our facility and soon, our app, will be the place to help you build the robots of the future, not be replaced by them. You can learn much more than robotics though - learn to create videos for YouTube, or make an animation, code, 3D print and design video games - learn it all at TinkerTank.

Skills like coding will be essential to jobs - and coding will likely be the next blue collar job. Robotics will be a hotly contested work area as companies compete on the best way to automate other work places. Creative industries will be attempting to use novel and creative ways through technology to communicate a message or advertisement. Video content producers will be everywhere - now everyone has access to a platform as large as any television conglomerate. 

Don’t be afraid. Don’t be scared. Be motivated and be prepared. TinkerTank is here to help - you can do courses that teach you certain skills over a term or the holidays, or you can become a member and use the space as you desire - getting direction from our staff and turning your ideas into reality. These experiences are fun, self-driven and totally open-ended. At TinkerTank no idea is too ambitious, no goal is out of the question... don’t believe me? Become a member today and try me*. [Book here](https://app.tinkertank.ai/?source=sales&type=Membership)

Memberships are ages 8+ (so no, you’re not too old!)


Thanks!

*James*

***If you want to make a real-world dragon... we might have reservations about that. But if you have a product, a real-world solution or a personal goal that you’re not quite sure you have the skills to make happen, then try TinkerTank - there’s no better place to try and make ideas reality.**

posts.meta_title: Don't Be Scared - STEAM is much safer than you think...

posts.title: You Choose - We Deliver!
posts.markdown:
Things are changing at TinkerTank and we think you're going to **love** it. Normally, after-school activities at TinkerTank have been a little confusing. No more! We have *really* simplified the process.

#####Let's explore:

Typically, when you chose an after-school activity at TinkerTank you have to consider the follow before booking:

* Term
* Course Type (Robotics, Coding, 3D Printing, Animation, Game Design, etc.)
* Age Group
* Time/Day of the week
* Skill Level

This was clogging up our sales view, and just offering way more options than was necessary. On top of that, it actually contradicted one of our core values at TinkerTank: project based learning. Project based learning says that you build your skills progressively through activities and projects *not* by selling artificial barriers and limitations based on a 'skill level'. So here's what's new. When you select an after-school or holiday activity, this is what you need to consider:

* Time/Day of the week
* Activity (Robotics, Coding, Design)
* That's it!

We no longer separate on age: you build your skills as you go, regardless of age or experience. 

We no longer separate on 'skill level'. We build skills continually as you go - we think that way you're never artificially limited in what you can achieve.

We hope this make life easier for you as a parent, and we hope that for you, our students, TinkerTank is the place that helps you discover your passion for STEAM. 

Let's work together to make us all #futureproof.

####[Book Now](https://app.tinkertank.ai/?source=sales&type=Subscription)

Book Now

posts.title: Disruption comes from grass roots effort
